The critical temperature (Tc) of a superconducting material is the temperature below which the material exhibits superconductivity, i.e., zero electrical resistance. The Tc of a material depends on its composition and crystal structure. Alterations to the crystal structure can lead to changes in the Tc. For example, introducing impurities or defects in the crystal lattice can either increase or decrease the Tc, depending on the nature of the impurities and their interaction with the superconducting electrons.

External magnetic fields can also affect the superconducting properties of a material. When a superconductor is exposed to an external magnetic field, it will expel the magnetic field from its interior, a phenomenon known as the Meissner effect. However, when the external magnetic field exceeds a critical value (Hc), the superconducting state is destroyed, and the material becomes a normal conductor. This critical magnetic field also depends on the temperature and the material's composition and crystal structure.

To determine the critical temperature of a specific superconducting material like XYZ, you would need to refer to experimental data or perform experiments yourself.
